awd_titl_txt: EARS: Adaptive Behavioral Responses for Dynamic Spectrum Access-Based Connected Vehicle Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Connected vehicle technology has the ability to provide drivers with a significantly higher level of environmental awareness relative to the present day. Thus, enabling reliable, seamless, and efficient wireless access to support vehicular connectivity is core to this safety technology. This project studies an approach that combines vehicular wireless networking with foraging theory, a concept that is extensively employed to describe the behavior of bumblebees. Specifically, the research will draw parallels between vehicular networks and bumblebees foraging for nectar in order to establish a novel framework for enhancing the performance of connected vehicles. This interdisciplinary project will make an educational contribution via the mentorship and training of graduate students from both Electrical & Computer Engineering and the Biological Sciences, with an emphasis on identifying qualified students from underrepresented groups.

In order to achieve a reliable and efficient connected vehicle networking architecture, this project studies how dynamic spectrum access (DSA)-based vehicular networks can be combined with foraging theory concepts. Although wireless networking research has previously looked to the insect world for insights on real-time decision-making across multiple communication nodes within a network in order to achieve some level of distributed optimization, e.g., ant colony optimization, honeybee swarm techniques, all of these approaches significantly depend on the high level of social dependency and information exchange found in these species in order to perform these operations. Conversely, bumblebees have been characterized as socially sharing past and present information with other bumblebees, but are still capable of making independent decisions, which is very similar to nodes within a vehicular networking environment. The application of mathematical tools used to temporally weigh the information shared between vehicular networking nodes as well as predict conditions in the near-future, such as autoregressive moving average (ARMA) filters and Kalman filters, have never been employed in models used to describe bumblebee behavior. Consequently, this effort could make an impact on biological sciences by providing mathematical tools that can be employed during the information weighing process of bumblebees.

por.por_cntn:
Self-driving cars, trucks, buses, and other modes of ground transportation have witnessed substantial growth over the past decade. An essential ingredient for the realization of these autonomous platforms is reliable, low delay, high speed wireless connectivity.  Seamless information sharing between vehicles as well as with roadside infrastructure (signage, traffic signals, etc) is critical for making informed decisions and ensuring accurate situational awareness. However, with limited dedicated frequency bands to support vehicular wireless communications, enabling large-scale connectivity amongst hundreds or even thousands of vehicles on the road could result in a spectral traffic jam, preventing time-sensitive and mission-critical information exchanges. This project yielded outcomes that will help enable reliable access to a limited amount of frequency bands by a large number of vehicles to facilitate information exchange.  The foundation of these outcomes is the application of bumblebee foraging behavioral models, a form of resource optimization perfected via evolution, to spectrally opportunistic vehicular networking called ?Vehicular Dynamic Spectrum Access? or VDSA to create a bumblebee-inspired VDSA (B-VDSA) networking framework.  The B-VDSA proposed framework makes efficient use of available frequency bands to support large-scale vehicular connectivity by exploiting the time, space, and frequency characteristics of communication network traffic along the road and to optimize access to minimize these spectral traffic jams. The outcomes using the B-VDSA framework include new mathematical formulations for the resource optimization that can be used in other disciplines, B-VDSA implementations in highly correlated and complex vehicular arrangements such as platooning, and proof-of-concept B-VDSA testbeds using the 5G wireless networking standard and software-defined radio (SDR) technology.

Intellectual Merit:

  • Memoryless B-VDSA framework designed to enable operating road vehicles to opportunistically access spectrum on an independent basis while still obtaining situational awareness information from neighboring vehicles.
  • Established a theoretical upper bound on the performance of the memoryless B-VDSA framework to assess the overall ability of the network to achieve data capacity given limited spectrum as a function of the number of actively transmitting vehicles and their level of transmit activity.
  • Implemented hardware proof-of-concept testbed focused on studying the performance of the B-VDSA algorithm inside a controlled laboratory environment using ADALM-Pluto SDR platforms. We showed the novelty of the bumblebee algorithm for optimal channel selection in a steady state environment and compared its performance with a random channel selection algorithm (an increase of 158.33% in network throughput was observed with our algorithm).
  • Implemented another hardware proof-of-concept testbed that explored the performance of the B-VDSA algorithm using the actual C-V2X protocol stack in real-world conditions using SDR hardware and the OpenAirInterface (OAI) software environment in an indoor closed experimentation system.
  • Devised a distributed B-VDSA framework for vehicles operating in platoon formations, where intra-platoon data traffic is off-loaded to spectral white-spaces in order to enhance vehicular connectivity in support of on-road operations. Simulation results show the distributed VDSA framework improves the leader packets reception ratio by 5%, thus indicating its potential to increase in reliability of intra-platoon communications.
  • Explored the impact of memory B-VDSA frameworks, especially with the data collected for the memory is non-uniformly sampled across different frequency channels in both the temporal and spectral dimensions.  Algorithms were developed to enable this non-uniform spectral-temporal sampling based on spectral occupancy of different vehicles operating in a VDSA-enabled platoon.

Broader Impacts: This project trained a total of three PhD students and two REU undergraduate students.  One offering of ECE4305 "Software Defined Radio Systems and Analysis" (~16 students) were also directly involved with this project (they implemented the B-VDSA algorithm as part of their course project), which led to their professional growth as future communication system innovators and leaders (a conference paper was also published on their resulting outputs). All three PhD students were involved in the mentorship of junior graduate students and undergraduate students in the corresponding research laboratories. This included the mentorship of both ECE and biology students pursuing their senior design capstone projects on topics related to this NSF-funded effort (at WPI, these are referred to as Major Qualifying Projects or MQPs).  Several high school students related to this project were also mentored during a high school summer research program that ran for three summers. Two tutorials focused on the B-VDSA work of this project were also presented at two summer schools to an audience of approximately 30 individuals (one was the NSF WiFiUS summer school hosted at Northeastern University and the other was presented at the IEEE VTS CAV Summer School hosted at the Boston Seaport campus of Worcester Polytechnic Institute). Results from this work have been presented via peer-reviewed publications (journals and conferences), tutorial presentations, invited and keynote talks, poster presentations, website, and media outlets.
